title: Rugby World Cup chiefs to decide on Scotland vs Japan match 'as soon as possible'
text:

Scotland are still waiting to discover their World Cup fate after tournament bosses said they will undergo a venue inspection ahead of Sunday's clash with Japan.

Typhoon Hagibis is due to strike the eastern coast of Japan on Saturday, with the 1400km-wide super cyclone predicted to cause widespread damage.

Scotland's must-win clash against Japan is due to take place at Yokohama's International Stadium, but there are fears it will be cancelled, which would mean World Cup elimination for Gregor Townsend's team.

Reports have suggested an inspection of the stadium will take place at 6am Japan time on the morning of the game (10pm Saturday BST), with a decision due two hours later.

But the tournament organisers say they will only be able to make that call once it is safe enough for inspections to take place.

(Image: FRANCK ROBICHON/EPA-EFE/REX)

A World Rugby spokesman said: "Our primary consideration is the safety of everyone.

"We will undertake detailed venue inspections as soon as practically possible with an announcement following as soon as decisions are made in the morning.

"Our message to fans continues, stay indoors today, stay safe and monitor official Rugby World Cup social and digital channels."

Hagibis is set to become Japan's biggest storm in 51 years and is expected to have a major impact on the country's transport and rail networks.

(Image: SNS Group)

(Image: Getty Images)

It could play a part in whether the game is allowed to go ahead, with a closed door match still a possibility.

World Rugby must make a final decision on whether the game goes ahead no later than six hours before the 7.45pm (11.45am BST) kick-off time.

Scotland must beat the Brave Blossoms to qualify for the quarter-finals. If they match is called off, it will be declared a draw and they will exit the competition.
description: World Rugby hope to hold venue inspection at Yokohama stadium on Saturday night
